channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Money Matters: When to Pay Off Student Loans?
item.description: Submit your money woes here. If you think an investment will return more than your highest interest rate, you might want to start investing some money. Say your only debt is a student loan at 5% interest. If you think an investment will return more than 5% this year, investing might be a good shout. Should college grads start investing before paying off all student loans?
item.author: Ryan Lasker

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 3
item.description: (The Atlantic)   Read: The three simple rules that underscore the danger of Delta. The positive test means she won’t be able to compete in the 100-meter race at the Tokyo Olympics, but could be available for the 4x100 meter relay.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Five Fast Firework Facts for the Fourth
item.description: Not helping: 90% of US fireworks are made in China, so logjams at ports over there mean a reduction or delay in getting supply over here. Massachusetts is the only state with a total ban on the sale of consumer fireworks. Thanks, Ben Affleck. 5.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Get to Know Amazon’s New CEO, Andy Jassy
item.description: Not long after, Jassy changed Amazon forever by coming up with and executing on the idea for Amazon’s cloud computing service, Amazon Web Services, which he currently leads.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: US Economy Adds 850,000 Jobs in June in Bullish Sign for Labor Market
item.description: The US economy added 850,000 jobs in June, marking the biggest monthly gain in almost a year and topping expectations. The 850,000 headline number represents a big improvement from May’s jobs report (+583,000 jobs) and April’s (+269,000). Economists hope that the increase in job seekers in June is a sign the labor crunch could smooth out by fall. Challenges remain, of course.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Get to Know Amazon’s New CEO, Andy Jassy
item.description: Not long after, Jassy changed Amazon forever by coming up with and executing on the idea for Amazon’s cloud computing service, Amazon Web Services, which he currently leads.

item.title: US Economy Adds 850,000 Jobs in June in Bullish Sign for Labor Market
item.description: The 850,000 headline number represents a big improvement from May’s jobs report (+583,000 jobs) and April’s (+269,000). The US economy added 850,000 jobs in June, marking the biggest monthly gain in almost a year and topping expectations.  A few other major themes from the jobs reportLeisure and hospitality 📈: The sector most battered by the pandemic added 343,000 jobs in June, accounting for 40% of the total gains.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Five Fast Firework Facts for the Fourth
item.description: Not helping: 90% of US fireworks are made in China, so logjams at ports over there mean a reduction or delay in getting supply over here. Massachusetts is the only state with a total ban on the sale of consumer fireworks. Thanks, Ben Affleck. 5.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Origin Stories: July Fourth’s Favorite Companies
item.description: Nathan’s Hot DogsYes, a guy named Nathan did actually start this company. Old Navy became the first clothing company to reach $1 billion in sales in its first four years of business. What’s up with the matching Old Navy shirts in every single one of our family pics? In 2012, Solo was acquired by Dart Container for $1 billion, and according to the company’s website, fans post 400,000+ photos with the iconic red cup every year.  Red Solo cupIt’s the early 1930s in Chicago, and disposable cups are all the rage after the city council banned the use of germy “common drinking cups” 20 years before. The contest, where competitors have 10 minutes to inhale as many hot dogs as they can, has aired live on ESPN since 2004. Why is Nathan's the first name you think of when you picture a hot dog? In 1916, Nathan Handwerker began selling hot dogs in New York’s Coney Island for five cents.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Make It Work: How to Address a Pay Gap Issue
item.description: Hey Kate, I recently discovered that I am being paid 25%–33% less than my male colleagues working in the same position with the same level of education and work experience. Each week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021.  If you don’t get a positive response, maybe it’s time to look for an employer that values your talents and experience. Be clear, specific, and confident!
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers With...Beeple
item.description: And that's not a part of NFTs.What is the future of NFTs? NFTs will be part of your life, just because they'll be the easiest way to prove that you own things. This WENEW project is one new use case for NFTs. As more use cases come, more people will learn about this technology and see value in it for something that connects to their lives.  It's been really exciting to be a part of something that feels like it's the beginning. It’s still the most expensive NFT ever sold.  The other thing that is tough for people to understand is that one of the main aspects of ownership with many things is being able to restrict access to that thing. They’ll be attached to a bunch of different things that make it easy to prove that you are the one single person that has that thing.  You’ve had quite a year, selling an NFT for $69 million. It’s a super exciting time, and I feel very honored to be a part of that.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 2
item.description: (New York Times) —Wally FunkRead: Joe Rogan is too big to cancel. You can still do it if you want to do it and I like to do things that nobody has ever done.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: 130 Countries Agree to Global Minimum Corporate Tax Rate
item.description: For the past 30 years, countries have lowered their corporate tax rates to lure companies to their shores.  Big picture: Under a global minimum tax, multinational corporations would theoretically stop moving their headquarters to tax havens like the British Virgin Islands and Bermuda.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Robinhood Announces IPO After $70 Million Finra Fine
item.description: For instance, Robinhood wants you to buy into Robinhood’s IPO on Robinhood. In an unusual move, it’s setting aside 20%–35% of its Class A stock for its customers, as opposed to bankers. US-listed IPOs have already raised over $190 billion so far in 2021, more than 2020’s total.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Name, Image, and Likeness Relaxations Creates New Industry Overnight
item.description: + Further NIL reading: The top 20 athletes who could capitalize on NIL and the earning potential of athletes across sports and endorsement deals. 25 states passed NIL bills that challenged the NCAA’s rules banning student athletes from monetizing their popularity. For example, industry insiders expect LSU gymnast Olivia Dunne to earn the most of any NCAA athlete from NIL endorsements.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Name, Image, and Likeness Relaxations Creates New Industry Overnight
item.description: + Further NIL reading: The top 20 athletes who could capitalize on NIL and the earning potential of athletes across sports and endorsement deals. 25 states passed NIL bills that challenged the NCAA’s rules banning student athletes from monetizing their popularity. The relaxation of rules governing name, image, and likeness (NIL) allows college athletes to sign endorsement deals and make money off their fame for the first time, resulting in a “transcendent day for American sports,” Sports Illustrated writes.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: 130 Countries Agree to Global Minimum Corporate Tax Rate
item.description: Big picture: Under a global minimum tax, multinational corporations would theoretically stop moving their headquarters to tax havens like the British Virgin Islands and Bermuda. For the past 30 years, countries have sprinted to lower their corporate tax rates to lure companies to their shores.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: New York Has The Worst Traffic In The US
item.description: Zoom out: The average metropolitan driver spent ~41 hours in traffic last year, but drivers in the US’ five most-congested metro areas spent much more:New York-Newark: 56Boston: 50Houston: 49Los Angeles-Long Beach-Anaheim: 46San Francisco-Oakland: 46Bottom line: Like the Knicks’ playoff appearance, this traffic ranking is a pandemic-era anomaly.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 1
item.description: (New Yorker) Read: What deadlines do to lifetimes. The department, whose alumni include Meryl Streep and Lupita Nyong’o, will be renamed the David Geffen School of Drama at Yale, proving nothing is truly free.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Amazon Files Motion to Remove Lina Khan From the Company’s Antitrust Investigations
item.description: Amazon filed a motion yesterday to keep Federal Trade Commission Chairwoman Lina Khan out of ongoing antitrust investigations because of her past criticisms of the company. The Yale Law grad was sworn in as chair of the FTC this month.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Finra Levies Robinhood Its Biggest Fine Ever
item.description: Some examples:A feature that was supposed to allow users to block their ability to trade with borrowed money did not work for certain trades. Finra accused Robinhood of misleading customers and for failing to provide support to them when asked. Glitches resulted in traders seeing inaccurate balances. Its IPO paperwork is expected any day now.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: China's Communist Party Turns 100
item.description: Since the liberalization of China’s economy, the country has developed a close business relationship with the West—just last week Nike’s CEO said, “Nike is a brand that is of China and for China.”  After the Communists gained power in the 1949 revolution, Mao initiated a series of disastrous economic reforms that led to the deaths of tens of millions of people. Bottom line: At 100 years old, the Communist Party remains a potent global force led by a president who could be the first since Mao to rule until he dies. Its caginess around the origins of Covid-19 has made things worse.
item.author: Neal Freyman

Since the liberalization of China’s economy, the country has developed a close economic relationship with the West—just last week Nike’s CEO said, “Nike is a brand that is of China and for China.” Bottom line: At 100 years old, the Communist Party remains a potent global force led by a president who could be the first since Mao to rule until he dies.

item.title: The Top Five Business Stories of Q2
item.description: Inflation scaries With prices increasing at rates not seen in years, the No. 1 business story of the quarter could only be inflation. The number of companies citing inflation in their earnings calls hit a 10-year high, Chipotle hiked its menu prices, and at one point in April the cheapest rental car on Maui was a Toyota Camry that cost $722 a day. Fed Chair Jerome Powell has argued higher inflation is mostly transitory, while legendary investor Paul Tudor Jones responded, “that one just doesn’t work the way I see the world.” More Americans quit in May than any month on record. Yet lingering health concerns, childcare responsibilities, and generous unemployment payments have kept Americans from returning to the labor force. With the economy reawakening faster than expected, employers are desperate to hire employees to meet demand. Help wanted9.3 million. 2. For example, in Mississippi less than a third of the population is fully vaccinated.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Time Capsule: Q2 2021
item.description: Here are some of the craziest facts we learned: College coaches were the highest-paid public employees in 40 states in 2019. More twins are being born now than at any point in history.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Facebook Launches Bulletin, Its Subscription Newsletter Service
item.description: Zoom out: Bulletin is Facebook’s latest product that chases individual creators; its previous launch was a Clubhouse competitor for live audio content, which Zuck used to announce Bulletin. The other major competitor in the space is Twitter, after it purchased newsletter platform Revue in January.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 30
item.description: (Paul Graham) Read: How to work hard.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: SpaceX’s Starlink Internet Service Has 69,420 Users
item.description: Musk said Starlink could make up to $30 billion in revenue per year—about 10 times the revenue of the rocket-launching side of SpaceX. Starlink provides internet via a network of over 1,500 satellites orbiting low enough for stargazers to spot them overhead.    But like cheap printers with expensive ink, Starlink hopes to recoup initial costs later on. 69,420, SpaceX CEO Elon Musk said yesterday.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: US Home Price Growth Hits a Record High in April
item.description: Actually, experts predict the housing market won’t implode like it did 10 years ago. Home prices in cities like Phoenix, San Diego, and Seattle are all up more than 20% year over year. “People are kind of burnt out.” Sounds pretty bubbly, right? Another buyer in Austin, TX, bought two houses from the same seller so he could get the one he really wanted.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: United Makes Big Bet on the Future of Air Travel
item.description: Yes, we mean actual business travel “Everything we see every week makes us even more certain that business travel and international travel are ultimately going to come back,” United CEO Scott Kirby said. Fast forward to yesterday, and United Airlines just placed its largest plane order ever and the biggest of any airline in a decade. One does not simply order 270 state-of-the-art planes worth more than $30 billion and then leave them unused in the hangar.
item.author: Neal Freyman

He said Starlink could make up to $30 billion in revenue per year—about 10 times the revenue of the rocket-launching side of SpaceX.
